scenes.background: The team has successfully completed an important project, and everyone is excited to organize a celebration. However, there are differing opinions on how to celebrate. Colleague Sam suggests going to a bar for a lively party, Emma prefers a formal dinner, and Ryan proposes an outdoor team-building activity. Alex suggests a bit of everything: starting with an outdoor activity, then having dinner, and ending the night at a bar. Monica and Bob have been discussing this, and you notice some tension as they approach you. Alex then suggests a middle ground: a team-building activity followed by dinner, saving the bar for another time. Monica crosses her arms and says, 'Alex, do you really think we can fit all that in one evening? And Bob here thinks we should just stick to one thing.' Bob nods in agreement, looking a bit annoyed. Alex suggests a compromise with a bistro that’s casual but still has great food. Monica raises an eyebrow and says, 'Even with your compromise, we still need to decide on the dinner venue. Bob prefers a fancy restaurant, but I think a casual place would be more relaxed.' Bob sighs, clearly frustrated. Alex proposes a quick poll to see what most of the team prefers. Monica leans back in her chair, looking at you expectantly, while Bob frowns and says, 'I just don’t see how we can make everyone happy with this plan.'
scenes.description: Monica taps her fingers on the table and says, 'I just want to make sure everyone has a good time. Bob, you seem really attached to the fancy restaurant idea. Why is that?' Bob shrugs and says, 'I think it’s a fitting way to celebrate our hard work.'

options.text: I get it, Bob. A fancy restaurant does have its appeal. Maybe we can find a balance with a place that offers a sophisticated atmosphere but isn’t too formal.
options.analysis: This response shows a high level of emotional detection and empathy by acknowledging Bob's preference and attempting to find a balanced solution. It demonstrates good social skills and motivation.

options.text: I understand where you’re coming from, Bob. But maybe we should prioritize what's most practical and enjoyable for the majority of the team.
options.analysis: This choice shows good self-regulation and social skills, but slightly lower empathy as it emphasizes practicality over individual preferences.

options.text: Honestly, I think we’re overthinking this. Let’s just pick a place that’s convenient and focus on enjoying each other’s company.
options.analysis: This option balances emotional detection and social skills but lacks strong empathy or motivation as it downplays the importance of finding a perfect venue.
